Violation_Type: Failure to adequately assess operational effectiveness of state protection
Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's finding of adequate state protection in Hungary was reasonable
Application_Facts: Applicant is a 77-year-old Roma woman from Hungary claiming persecution due to racism
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, quashing of decision, and reconsideration
Court_Ruling: Decision quashed; remanded for reconsideration by a different panel
Defendant_Behavior: RPD dismissed claim based on presumption of state protection without sufficient analysis
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution due to racial discrimination and fascist violence
Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life under sections 96 and 97 IRPA
Assessment_Factor: Operational adequacy of state protection against fascist violence
Applicable_Legislation: Sections 96, 97, and subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Used: Evidence of Hungaryâ€™s efforts to combat discrimination
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution based on ethnicity
Evidence_Assessed: Lack of focus on operational effectiveness of protective measures
Governing_Rule: Presumption of state protection unless rebutted by evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to address operational adequacy of state protection
Harm_Assessment: Risk of persecution due to Roma identity and age
Cause_Description: Applicant feared persecution in Hungary due to her Roma ethnicity
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient assessment of evidence regarding state protection mechanisms
Evidence_Issues: Inadequate consideration of evidence on fascist violence and state response
Evidence_Assessment: Analysis lacked focus on operational adequacy of state protection
Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to reasonably assess whether Hungary could effectively protect the applicant from fascist violence
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection with sufficient evidence on operational effectiveness
